stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the layout for a desert pyramid level. He critiqued and ultimately scrapped his initial maze-like design due to gameplay and camera issues, then brainstormed and began modeling a new concept based on a central hub with multiple floors and warping tunnels.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to completely scrap the initial layout for the pyramid level after identifying major gameplay and camera issues, opting for a new design based around a central hub.
development_findings.quote: Sucks I did all this but most of this is reusable. So it's fine. It's fine. It's fine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered a new technique to implement vertex coloring on Mario's model at no performance cost, allowing for details like shaded areas and a shine on his shoes.
development_findings.quote: I realized I can use the blend mode and set cycle 1 alpha to just shade color and effectively vertex color him that way by lerping into black. Isn't that cool?

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes the free-to-play nature of the game means the opening levels must be exceptionally high quality to hook players, as there is no financial investment to retain them.
development_findings.quote: This is going to be your first impression of the game it has to be absolute peak. The fact that this game doesn't cost money in a way that's really bad news for us.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing completion, with the team reportedly working on the 'last two courses'. The main content is estimated to be finished in 2025, to be followed by beta testing.
The new pyramid level design involves a multi-story central room with six tunnels, some of which are one-way and others are two-way, using instant warps to create complex but manageable navigation.
Kaze uses Blender as his level editor and relies on a script called 'fast64' to export his work into a format compatible with the N64 engine.
development_findings.quote: There's this a script called fast 64 and exports all of this to n64 formats so that's how I transfer the there you go me dancing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frugal and believes his lifestyle has not significantly changed with more income, suggesting that buying things is often a misplaced search for happiness.
context_findings.quote: I used to make like $7,000 a year and I don't think my life has changed much since then. I still just live like I make $7,000 a year.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is fully aware that Nintendo might issue a takedown notice for the game upon release but considers it a calculated risk worth taking to complete his creative vision.
context_findings.quote: It was a calculated risk. I still wanted to do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes novel and interesting game design, even if it's more complex or risky, over using conventional, well-trodden solutions.
context_findings.quote: I mean yes that that would be like a fun thing, but I feel like game design wise it's not as interesting. It's something that's been done like a million times before. I wanted to try something new.

context_findings.summary: Kaze deeply admires the design philosophy of 'The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask,' preferring its focus on the world and the journey over a dungeon-centric structure.
context_findings.quote: Majora's Mask you only have four dungeons but roughly the same playtime and that is because in Majora's Mask it's not just so much about doing the dungeons themselves it's about the journey to get into the dungeon.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of the current trend of integrating AI into applications where he feels it is unnecessary and unwanted, like text editors.
context_findings.quote: The AI situation is a little bizarre to me. It seems very evident to me that no one wants it, but somehow it keeps being added to things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that having a baby has been a more significant life change for his wife, Zeina, than for himself, as she is the primary caregiver.
context_findings.quote: For me, as my wife is mainly caring for the child, she's a stay at home mom. So for me, it was just work before and it's mostly just work after. So it's going to have been a much, much bigger change for her.

biobak.summary: Kaze trusts Biobak to handle and fix graphical elements, indicating a workflow where Kaze creates placeholder or initial models that Biobak later refines.
biobak.quote: I know it looks poofy right now but Biobak said it's gonna move it so I'm not worrying about it for now.

biobak.summary: Kaze and Biobak share a casual and humorous rapport, as seen in their back-and-forth jokes in the stream chat about Pokémon cards and personal grooming.

zeina.summary: A story about a broken water pitcher reveals a playful domestic dynamic between Kaze and Zeina, stemming from different household habits.
zeina.quote: The situation I just described, do you think it was my fault that it broke or it was Zeina's? We're not a hundred percent in agreement over whose fault it is quite yet.

zeina.summary: Zeina is Kaze's spouse and a stay-at-home mother to their baby. She recently took the baby on a weekend trip, giving Kaze time to work.
Kaze shared a humorous and awkward story from Halloween where he and Zeina attempted to give candy to neighbor's children, resulting in a misunderstanding.
zeina.quote: So Zayna bought the really, really hot Takis... and this is the candy she gave to the children. Are they going to think we like tried to kill their children?

key_stories.title: The Pyramid's Downfall and Rebirth
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified critical gameplay and camera flaws in his pyramid level. After discussing with his stream chat, he scrapped the entire layout in favor of a new concept built around a central hub, demonstrating his willingness to make major design changes based on feedback and playtesting.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the pyramid level was a confusing maze with severe camera issues and tedious backtracking, making it unfun to play.
key_stories.process: Kaze playtested the level live, verbalized its flaws, and discussed potential solutions with his stream chat. He embraced a suggestion for a central room, decided to scrap the current layout, and immediately began modeling the new concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze abandoned the flawed design in favor of a new concept built around a central hub with warping tunnels. This new design is more robust, less frustrating, and allows for the reuse of existing geometric assets.
key_stories.key_quote: This section here fucking sucks and we need a simpler way to get back up to the top of the pyramid.

key_stories.title: The Calculated Risk of a Takedown
key_stories.summary: Kaze openly contemplates the inevitable risk of a Nintendo takedown. He accepts it as a 'calculated risk,' expressing more frustration with predictable community reactions than the legal threat itself, and is planning strategies to mitigate the impact on the game's release.
key_stories.challenge: The project, being an unauthorized modification of a Nintendo game, faces a significant risk of being legally targeted and taken down upon its release.
key_stories.process: Kaze openly discussed the likelihood of a takedown notice. He has considered strategies to mitigate the immediate impact, like preparing a copyright-free trailer. He expressed more frustration with the anticipated smug comments from the community than with the legal threat itself.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has accepted the risk and is proceeding with development. He is focused on creating the game he envisions, despite the potential consequences for its public availability and fame.
key_stories.key_quote: Yes I knew this was going to happen but I didn't know it was going to happen. The fuck is your point? It still sucks. It was a calculated risk I still wanted to do it.

key_stories.title: The Broken Pitcher Incident
key_stories.summary: A story about a broken water pitcher reveals a humorous domestic disagreement between Kaze and Zeina. It highlights their different household habits and serves as a jumping-off point for Kaze to explain his philosophy on efficiency and principle.
key_stories.challenge: A mundane household incident—a broken water pitcher—led to a disagreement with his wife, Zeina.
key_stories.process: Kaze recounted how he broke his water pitcher after placing it precariously on a sink that Zeina was using to store dirty dishes. This sparked a debate over who was at fault and a broader discussion on household chores and principles.
key_stories.outcome: The story revealed insights into Kaze's and Zeina's domestic dynamic, their differing habits, and served as a vehicle for Kaze to explain his strong belief in efficiency, particularly his preference for dishwashers over washing by hand.
key_stories.key_quote: The situation I just described, do you think it was my fault that it broke or it was Zeina's? We're not a hundred percent in agreement over whose fault it is quite yet.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak would refine a model he made, implying a handoff process. Badub was not mentioned at all. The dynamic with Zeina is personal.
questions: How does the asynchronous collaboration with Biobak work? What does a typical creative handoff look like?
Can you describe the feedback loop between yourself, Biobak, and Badub?
How do you and Zeina navigate the boundary between your personal relationship and her contributions or influence on the project?
What is Badub's current role and level of involvement in this late stage of development?

open_questions.context: Kaze said his life hasn't changed much since earning more money and that he remains frugal. He also stated the game being free is 'bad news' because it removes player investment.
questions: You've mentioned being very frugal. How does your personal financial philosophy influence how you manage a massive, non-commercial project like this?
How do you justify the immense time investment, which could be spent on paid work, for a passion project that you are giving away for free?

open_questions.context: Kaze spoke passionately about his preference for Majora's Mask's world-focused design over Ocarina of Time's dungeon-centric one. He also briefly mentioned an unnamed game as inspiration for the pyramid redesign.
questions: You mentioned an old game your brother owned inspired the pyramid's new design. What was that game and what specific elements did you draw from it?
How has the design philosophy of 'Majora's Mask' directly influenced specific levels or mechanics in 'Return to Yoshi's Island' beyond a general preference?
Are there other, less obvious games that have shaped your design principles for this hack?

open_questions.context: Kaze excitedly explained a 'free of cost' technique he discovered to add vertex color shading to Mario's model using blend modes.
questions: Can you walk us through the moment you figured out the vertex color technique? Was it a solution to a long-standing problem or a sudden 'aha' moment?
How does this technical discovery impact the potential visual style of the game moving forward? Will you apply it to other models?
